text: hey joseline with Walter's world and
we've gotten an overwhelming number of
questions lately about where to take
kids like what's family-friendly so
today I want to give you some ideas
about where to take your kids but also
how to make Kings a little bit more
family-friendly I also want to give you
some tips on what to look for to make
things a little bit more fun for
everybody in the family so let's start
with a to-do list
kids love adventure right our kids the
places that they've enjoyed most are the
places that we've had outdoor activities
and adventures and you know those are
always great things to look for wherever
you go obviously things like beaches and
pools and all of that amusement parts
are kind of a given but I'm talking
about snorkeling out there in the
Caribbean or hiking in Iceland ziplining
in Costa Rica taking a bike tour around
the Grand Canyon there are so many
things that we've done with our kids and
they've been amazing wonderful
adventures and they really got us out
there and learned a lot more about
something because it was a little more
in-depth than a usual tour so if you're
not a really outdoorsy sort of family or
you have kids that don't really love the
outdoors there are all sorts of other
things to do we've done cooking classes
Caleb and I are taking a painting class
in Paris this summer I've signed up for
that months ago because I thought it
would just be perfect for the two of us
there's all sorts of great cultural
things you can go to schools and things
like that and all of those take a little
bit more planning you have to jump into
that a little bit earlier and start
researching maybe a little sooner than
you would just a cooking class but our
kids have loved it and then change so
much knowledge and empathy for other
people in in different walks of life and
it's just been a really awesome
experience so that makes things a little
bit more family friendly when you're in
a place that maybe isn't quite so
adventurous so on top of having fun
things to do there's always places that
you want to go that aren't just aren't
gonna be so much fun for the kids like
museums and things like that so when it
give you a couple of tips on how to
handle that
first and foremost don't schedule more
than maybe two museums and really I only
do one of one a day with the kids
because it just gets to be too much for
them but
can make that museum a lot more fun if
you do some a little bit of legwork
beforehand often museums have children's
programming so go to their website check
that out before you go but you can
always make yourself if they don't have
children's programming a scavenger hunt
you can tailor things for the ages of
your of each of your children by making
one scavenger hunt something a little
more difficult for the older kids or
whatever but you can always just put all
the things you want to see into that
scavenger hunt but make it fun for them
to find those things and learn a bit a
little bit on the side another way we
get our kids ready and excited about a
place is by showing them movies books
you know TV shows and what not about the
place that we're going before you before
we get there for instance the first time
we went to Rome we showed Caleb a Bugs
Bunny where he's at the Coliseum and
then we took him to the Coliseum and he
was you know he was three but he was so
excited he was like wow you know it
things like that just make it a little
bit more real for a kid and so try try
to see if you can find some of those
things beforehand another great thing
that we really enjoy is Lonely Planet
has a couple of series of books for kids
so once called city trails and another
one is not for parents and you can find
them for different regions of the world
continents even cities and different
countries and those things are putting
all the stuff that you're going to see
anyway into a kid's perspective and it's
a really great way to get them pumped up
usually those books are pretty thin so
you it's not something you would mind
packing into their backpack or whatever
so they can read it on the plane or take
it with them during the day and kind of
get an idea of what's going on in the
city some of those not for parents books
actually have things to do all day like
scavenger hunts throughout the city so
you can just kind of pop one of those in
their bag and really get them pumped up
about what they're gonna see another way
to get the kids excited is to get them
in on the planning we always ask our
kids you know where do you want to go
what do you see what do you want to see
when we're there what would interest you
the most in this place so maybe you just
give them a brief overview or if they're
older have them look
some stuff up on their own and kind of
wild down what they want to do and see
and get some of their input and do it
because then you're you're encouraging
them to travel but you're also
encouraging them to research and to
learn about a place before you get there
so one last tip for making things a
little bit more family-friendly
especially for young kids is to give
them equal play time if you go to a
museum let them play for about 10 or 15
minutes before you go to run off a
little extra energy don't get them too
tired though because when you get into
the museum and you're there for an hour
things don't go so well if they're
exhausted however after you get out
promised them if they behave well or you
know give them give them a little
incentive for good behavior and when you
get help go out and play if you're at
the Louvre just go right out and there's
tons of space out there let the kids run
play tag with them that's one of our
favorite things to do when we have a
little extra space or when dad's filming
a video so giving them a more equal play
time along with the humdrum sort of
stuff kind of makes them a little bit
more apt to assimilate to the stuff that
isn't really fun for them so some places
that our kids have really loved and that
we find to be intrinsically
family-friendly just generally southern
Europe Portugal Italy Spain Greece they
really love kids we've been invited to

but they've also gotten to meet locals

kids really enjoy going with Iceland

there's always something different to do
everywhere you go there's a different

changes from one end of the country to

as they as we drove around the country
but there's a lot to do and they enjoyed
every bit of it and the ice
people were really open to our kids
we've taken several really great family
road trips Ireland and Scotland or two
that always kind of stick in my head
because the people are really great with
our kids but also because there's a lot
to do outside we would stop just on the
side of the road because the kids are
like that looks like a great place to

know there's just a lot of ease when

don't have quite so many time

everywhere we go Costa Rica we went

Ecuador was really great Ecuador
actually had has all the Earth's biomes

and the kids learned a lot about the
earth about our planet about different
